item.title: Report E-2025030396
item.description:
Report E-2025030396

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-27T15:24:19+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-25
  • City: ALEXANDRIA
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: United Parcel Service
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On March 25, 2025, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN3109 was punctured and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Indiana Spill Response (ISR) to remediate the site. The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to clean the impacted area. All impacted materials and the damaged pail were containerized in one (1) 15-gallon drum for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2025030395
item.description:
Report E-2025030395

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-27T15:24:19+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-25
  • City: CLARION
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 15500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: First Call Environmental-LTL personnel arrived onsite and observed that an estimated five (5) gallons were released impacting an estimated 2’-by-2’ area. The released material was due to a load shift causing one (1) 5-gallon metal pail to be punctured. Once the telehandler arrived, they started unloading freight. They ceased work due to being unable to unload/reload a metal grate with product on it with the manpower and equipment they had. However, the driver called his safety manager who dispatched two drivers who had power pallet jackets to assist with moving the metal grate. If loaded in the original position, the freight risked puncturing another product. It was determined the metal grate should be taken on another truck instead of being reloaded in the same position. First Call Environmental-LTL deployed absorbents and containerized them into two (2) 55-gallon metal drums. All undamaged freight was loaded onto a new truck while the metal grate was loaded onto the original truck. Due to First Call Environmental-LTL not being able to hold hazardous waste, they took the generated waste the ESTES terminal in West Middlesex, Pennsylvania. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the site. The crew utilized absorbents and cleaning agents to clean the site. All impacted materials and the damaged pails were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

item.title: Report X-2025031265
item.description:
Report X-2025031265

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-27T15:24:19+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-18
  • City: ADDISON
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AT RC-1 SINGULATOR, BELT TENDER NOTICED HAZMAT PACKAGE HAD A WET SPOT ALL OVER HALF OF THE BOTTOM PORTION. BELT TENDER NOTIFIED RMP THROUGH THE RADIO ABOUT THE HAZMAT PACKAGE AND RMP NOTIFIED DESIGNATED RESPONDER. DESIGNATED RESPONDER ARRIVED AT RC-1 SINGULATOR WITH THEIR SPILL CART, FULL PPE ON, AND CURRENT DECISION TREE. DESIGNATED RESPONDER READ AND FOLLOWED THE CURRENT DECISION TREE, WHICH LEAD TO THE FLAMMABLE LIQUID RESPONSE SHEET SINCE THERE WAS A FLAMMABLE LIQUID LABEL. SINCE THERE WAS NO PUDDLE UNDERNEATH PACKAGE, NO ZEP ZORBENT WAS NEEDED. DESIGNATED RESPONDER CONTAINED FLAMMABLE LIQUID HAZMAT PACKAGE AND RETURNS BACK TO THE PSC CAGE. DESIGNATED RESPONDER STARTED PROCESSING THE FLAMMABLE LIQUID HAZMAT PACKAGE. AFTER PUTTING THE SOLIDIFIED CONTENTS AND CONTAMINATED CARDBOARD IN GREEN BAGS, DESIGNATED RESPONDER DECONTAMINATED THEIR PPE USED FROM THE RESPONSE.

item.title: Report I-2025030056
item.description:
Report I-2025030056

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-27T15:24:19+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-17
  • City: Cleveland
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: HIGHWAY TRANSPORT CHEMICAL, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Driver observed material leaking down the side of his tanker. Driver inspected the top of the tanker and observed there was no dome lid gasket. Driver reported to his Safety Department, and they called Environmental Management, Inc. (EMI) to initiate a response. EMI contacted a local subcontractor, Haz Mat Special Services (HMSS), to respond to the release. HMSS arrived and placed absorbents underneath the tanker. HMSS cleaned around the dome lid and crash box and then installed a new gasket and secured the dome lid. The side of the tanker was then wiped down with absorbent pads. A power Washer was used to wash the side of the tanker and all the reinstate was captured. The tanker was then moved forward and the absorbents swept up and, placed into a 55-gallon open-top drum. The area on the concrete parking lot, which was approximately 10 feet in diameter, was then power washed and the water collected. All waste was placed into the one (1) drum and removed from the site for disposal at a later date.

  • Description: On 3/13/2025 at approximately 2330 hours, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 749919 at the hub facility in Memphis, reporting a dangerous goods spill. The shipment consisted of one fiberboard box containing 48 plastic bags of powder, five of which appeared to have been damaged, resulting in spillage. The cause of the damage is unknown. The entire contents of the five damaged bags were evacuated. The remainder of the shipment was placed in a salvage drum and awaits an amended shipper's declaration for further transport.

item.description:

  • City: BROOKLYN
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 3/13/2025 at approximately 1900 hours, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 104644 at the station location in Maspeth, reporting undeclared dangerous goods. The shipment consisted of one padded envelope that contained 3 bottles of spray-on deodorant. The shipment was discovered to have the trademark rattling sound in aerosol containers. Further inspection confirmed the commodity as an undeclared aerosol shipment. The package was not prepared in accordance with IATA Regulations, missing the required markings, labeling, packaging and paperwork. The shipment is being held, pending an investigation by the FAA.

item.title: Report E-2025030252
item.description:
Report E-2025030252

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-27T15:24:19+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-04
  • City: CLACKAMAS
  • State: OR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ADVANCED CHEMICAL TRANSPORT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6142
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 3/4/2025, our forklift operator was moving totes out of the way to load trailers. He took a tote to the lower yard to make room on the dock. He misjudged how close he was to another tote and that the forks stuck out beyond the width of the tote. This resulted in the tote behind being punctured with a 4X2" hole. The forklift operator got help from a coworker right away, they were able to flip the tote on its side on a spill pallet. Once the tote was on the spill pallet, dock employees notified their supervisor. The forklift operator placed booms and spill pads to keep the material contained. A drum vac was used to vacuum up standing liquid from the ground. The supervisor immediately notified upper management about the spill. The supervisor was given a list of numbers to contact, one of those being Environmental Restitution to dispatch an emergency response (ER) team to respond to perform clean-up. Until the ER team arrived on-site, employees made sure everyone kept out of the area and that the spill was contained. Once the ER team got to work, they transferred the waste into a new tote. This included material from the spill pallet, drum vac drum, and the remaining material in the punctured tote. The ER team decontaminated everything, pH tests were taken and about 10 yards of soil was dug up and placed into a roll-off bin. We are waiting for sample results in order to dispose of the soil.

  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 02/27/2025, at 13:04 hours, CSXT personnel in the Florence Yard (Florence, SC) discovered TILX282086, a loaded tank car of Ethylene Glycol, leaking from top of the car. The car was isolated and the shipper, Sabic, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 2025-0227-00169). HEPACO, a CSXT response contractor, responded and found that six of six manway cover bolts were less than tool tight. Contractor personnel were able to secure five of the manway bolts but found the sixth manway bolt was stripped and unable to be tightened. The card was held pending further repair by a certified tank car repair shop. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative- Moustafa Mughrabi (713-430-2501).

  • Description: At 2314 ET, XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at terminal UDV. It was reported that approximately 100-gallons of "CHEM-AQUA 18104" released from (2) plastic drums due to improper loading. The release impacted inside of trailer #3194740. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and determined that terminal personnel are not capable of cleaning the release with PPE available on site. An ETA for cleanup will be provided once confirmed. ERTS notified Chemtrec, Chelsea provided report #2025022600235 Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 50-gallons of UN2920 Chem-Aqua 18104 product released impacting 15’x9’ area inside trailer and outside of the trailer due to the load shifting during transit. The contractors neutralized the released product and impacted surfaces with oil dri, then overpacked (2) 30-gallon plastic drums into (2) 55-gallon poly drums, broken up pallet into (1) 55-gallon poly drum, and impacted oil dri into (2) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2025030399
item.description:
Report E-2025030399

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-27T15:24:19+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-26
  • City: HIALEAH

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 12300
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 13:41 ET, XPO notified the Call Center of a cargo release and tote transfer at terminal NMF. It was reported that approximately 0.5 gallon of Chemtreat RL124B released from one 330 due to being crushed by freight stacked on top by previous terminal. The release impacted trailer #5634415 on dock #19, the tote has been transferred to the OSD area. Call Center reviewed the SDS with the caller and determined that terminal personnel are not capable of cleaning the release with PPE available on site, due to the product being class 8. Call Center will proceed to dispatch a contractor to the site to complete cleanup activities and tote transfer. An ETA will be provided once it is known. CHEMTREC has been notified of the spill, report #2025022600145 was given by Charlie. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 5-gallons of UN2693 Chemtreat RL1248 product released impacting 48’x1’ area of the trailer floor due to improper loading. The contractors neutralized the released product and impacted surfaces with ProAlkaline, then containerized (1) 55-gallon poly drum with the oil dri, alkaline powder and wood chips. The product was transferred to a new tote and damaged tote left for waste pickup. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage

item.title: Report I-2025030048
item.description:
Report I-2025030048

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-27T15:24:19+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-21
  • City: Philadelphia
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: AMERICAN AIRLINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At approximately 15:00, a passenger approached the, #5 flight attendant with a vape device that was actively heating up. The passenger stated that he had accidentally dropped the device in water in the Lavatory, causing it to malfunction. The#5 flight attendant immediately informed the purser.- The purser communicated the situation to the flight deck crew and attempted to locate the fire containment bag.- When the purser was unable to locate the bag, the#4 flight attendant took over the search.- Meanwhile, the#7 flight attendant(myself) and the#5 flight attendant proceeded to fill the containment bag with water.- Once located, the malfunctioning vape device was placed inside the containment bag and submerged in water to prevent further overheating or potential fire: The containment bag was sealed according to standard safety procedures.-The secured device was then stored in an empty cart in the aft galley for the remainder of the flight. The situation was successfully managed without further incident. The device remained stable inside the containment bag, and there were no reported safety concerns for passengers or crew.

item.title: Report E-2025030345
item.description:
Report E-2025030345

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-26T21:14:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-25
  • City: CARLISLE
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS FREIGHT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO-Logistics contacted ERTS regarding a leaking metal drum containing hazardous product, Nitric Acid. A contractor dispatched and observed an estimate 1-pint release onto the wooden trailer floor in a 1’x1’ area as a result of improper packaging. The contractor applied sodium bicarbonate to the release and applied oil dry as well as absorbent pads. The neutralized and impacted absorbents and PPE were containerized into one 55-gallon DF for waste disposal. XPO will manage all waste created from the response. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were involved in this incident.

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-24
  • City: WHITESTOWN
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Operations Supervisor III Keli Linn contacted safety report a Hazardous Spill. Keli stated they were removing a pallet containing UN3378, Sodium carbonate peroxyhydrate, 5.1, PG II, from trailer 552651. Keli stated they noticed that one bag on the side of the pallet was torn and had leaked inside of the plastic wrap. Keli stated she believes the tear in the bag was due to a load shift and the pallet rubbed against the wall of the trailer resulting in an 8-ounce spillage into the plastic wrap, and onto the trailer floor.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On March 21, 2025, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN760 had a faulty cap and leaked approximately one (1) cup of product to the trailer floor and drum lid. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Carolina Environmental Response Team, Inc. (CERT) to remediate the site. The crew replaced the damaged cap and utilized neutralizing agent as well as absorbents to collect the released product. All impacted absorbents were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2025030259
item.description:
Report E-2025030259

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-26T21:14:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-20
  • City: ELKTON
  • State: MD
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 8000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Hepaco personnel were dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, they observed an estimated two (2) gallons of material released from one (1) box containing two (2) 1-gallon plastic jugs punctured by a forklift. Hepaco personnel observed that the released material impacted 2 ft-by-2 ft area of dock floor concrete. Hepaco personnel deployed granular absorbents to neutralize the area and absorb the material containerizing them into one (1) 55-gallon poly drums. The incident generated a total of one (1) container. One (1) 55- gallon poly drum containing empty bottles / neutralized impacted absorbents / Cardboard. All impacted surfaces were confirmed to be neutral, and work was approved. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On March 19, 2025, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN1760 was punctured by a nail and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer floor and pavement below. R + L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the site. Crews utilized neutralizers and granular absorbents to the trailer and pavement to absorb the suspected product. All spent materials were collected with hand tools and containerized within one (1) 55-gallon poly drum.

The entire shipment was improperly prepared and has been rejected during inspection.

THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

item.title: Report I-2025030038
item.description:
Report I-2025030038

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-26T21:14:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-13
  • City: MIAMI
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: Global Crossing Airlines, Inc
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Global Crossing Airlines, Inc {GCXA} operates freighter services under an ACMI agreement with IBC Airways to Kingston, Jamaica and several cities inside Cuba. As of 02/15/2025, GCXA's Loadmasters; who accompany the aircraft as part of the crew, have detected several instances where Lithium Batteries were found as being undeclared in shipments prior to loading the aircraft. Since 02/15/2025, instructions from the Cargo Operations department of GCXA has been for the Loadmasters to remain vigilant and scrutinize all shipments that may be viewed as suspicious, i.e {labeling, marking on boxes, key words such as "generators" "batteries" etc) prior to loading any ULD's onboard the aircraft. On 03/13/2025, the Loadmasters working the flight scheduled for MIA-CFG-MIA, indicated at 07:08L that again {6th time since 02/15/25), Undeclared hazardous materials were found in the shipment prior to loading and consequently rejected the entire load. The instructions to the ground handler {NAS) was for them to break all the packages since the Loadmasters did not trust any items that were wrapped with black plastic shrink wrap. The Loadmasters reached out for guidance to the Cargo Operations leadership and was advised to stand firm on that decision to reject this shipment. The Loadasters instructed the ground handlers to begin inspecting the completed ULDs and eventually various items ranging from portable electric generators, undeclared car batteries to electric scooters were detected. IBC Airways were informed and eventually they cancelled the flight. The FAA CMT was informed of the events.

item.title: Report X-2025031021
item.description:
Report X-2025031021

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-26T21:14:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-12
  • City: JNU
  • State: AK
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: ALASKA AIRLINES, INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Undeclared hazmat found during screening. Other undeclared hazmat found with no release as follows. (Replicating questions 14-29) ALCOHOLS, N.O.S. (ETHANOL)//haz class 3 // UN 1987//not shipped as hazardous waste//not toxic by inhalation//not shipped under Exemption, Approval, or CA number//shipment was undeclared with no release//packaging type non-bulk/outer packaging plastic box//Aerosols, flammable//haz class 2.1 // UN 1950 //not shipped as hazardous waste//not toxic by inhalation//not shipped under Exemption, Approval, or CA number//shipment was undeclared with no release//packaging type non-bulk/outer packaging plastic box// petroleum distillates, N.O.S // haz class 3 // UN 1268 //not shipped as hazardous waste//not toxic by inhalation//not shipped under Exemption, Approval, or CA number//shipment was undeclared with no release//packaging type non-bulk/outer packaging plastic box AWB71913015 arrived from AS66/12. One piece, a blue cooler fell on the ramp and because the lid wasn't taped or anything like that, the lid opened, and its contents were spilled out. It was then that some aerosol cans and a chargeable lithium battery were discovered. The runner brought it over to the warehouse and alerted me to take a look. I was able to pull the contents out of the cooler and found more undeclared DG. There was a tote that was a part of the six lot, so I opened it up to see what was in it and discovered a lot of batteries and lighters. Pictures of everything found and all sides of each piece are attached.

item.title: Report I-2025030044
item.description:
Report I-2025030044

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-26T21:14:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-03
  • City: ANCHORAGE
  • State: AK
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: Everts Air Cargo
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 55000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Undeclared hazmat shipment of Lithium Batteries. 5760 used computers from bush Alaska to a re-seller via Anchorage Alaska. Lower Kuskokwim School District (LKSD) engaged with Second Life Mac (SLM)(a company from Skokie, IL) for them to buy their used computers, and provide all services to package and transport them. Because of the very remote location of the computers (Bethel, AK), the LKSD followed SLM's instructions to package and deliver to the airline. SLM instructed LKSD to not mark or label any of the packages, and to cover them under black shrink wrap, deliver to the airline, and the airline agent would take care of everything. Neither the Airline nor Airline Agent knew anything about this shipment. 5 pallets of these items were tendered to the Airline in Bethel, AK, and described by the shipper on our AWB as "ELECTRONICS". Shipper was asked if there were any hazardous materials in the shipment, and shipper answered NO. Shipper signed the Airline's AWB and initialed that there was no hazardous materials in the shipment. 5 pallets were flown from Bethel to Anchorage, AK, consignee notified 3 times without picking the freight up, and after 3 weeks, Airline contacted the Shipper and asked what to do with the shipment? Shipper contacted the Consignee, and they then responded that day, and arrived the next day on sight with marking and labeling to further move these pallets on FedEx. They applied the hazmat dimond label to the 5 pallets while on our ramp. It had rained, and some of the boxes got wet, soaking some contents in water, which initiated a damage freight claim process. No action was taken on the claim, because of two issues: one-freight charges have not been paid for, two-shipment was abandoned for three weeks with no communication from consignee. On March 5th, Airline was notified of a demand letter from a lawyer for a claimed damage amount. The demand letter was elevated to airline administration, and was the first time administration became aware of the hidden hazmat shipment. SLM has a third party involved, Jesse Carnahan with Lynx Enterprises (Wasilla, AK). The Airline does not know how much of or who is responsible for what between Lynx and SLM. Once administration became aware of the non-declared hazmat, an investigation ensued which led to this 5800.1 report. No release or damage to the lithium batteries has been declared.

item.description:
Report E-2025030388

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-26T21:14:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-27
  • City: COLUMBUS
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 11:15 EST, ERTS was contacted by XPO Logistics (BCO) about a cargo release. It was reported that due to improper loading, approximately 1 cup of Naphtha (hazardous - UN1268) was released. The caller stated that the released product was contained to the box container and did not impact the dock floor. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and they felt comfortable cleaning the release donning the proper PPE per SDS. The released product and damaged can with box will be placed into a 5-gallon metal drum and staged in OS&D. There were no drains, soils or waterways reported to have been impacted by the release. There is no regulatory reporting required for this release.

item.title: Report E-2025030054
item.description:
Report E-2025030054

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-26T21:14:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-26
  • City: WALBRIDGE
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 41500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 02/26/2025, at 16:34 hours, personnel in the CSXT Yard in Walbridge, OH, discovered UTLX209767, a residue tank car of Ethyl Acrylate, emitting a strong odor. The car was isolated and the shipper, Zeon Chemicals, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report #2025-02-26-0146). HEPACO, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found the car was actively releasing product vapors from the liquid line reducer bushing threads, vapor line reducer bushing threads, and vacuum relief valve (VRV). Contractor personnel applied thread tape and thread dope to secure the liquid line and vapor line bushing releases. Additionally, emergency containment measures were taken to reduce the odor/vapor emissions from the vacuum relief valve. Subsequently, additional contractor personnel were mobilized to safely depressurize the car, remove the faulty VRV, and install a blind flange to ensure the car was leak tight. The issue was identified, and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative- Sharen Panday (sharen.panday@us.sasol.com). The car was released for transport home shop under shipper OMTA.

  • Description: X-2025030992 During a FRA Hazmat inspection the inspector heard hissing coming from the vacuum relief device on tank car FURX130415. The inspector notified the RR of it and a contractor was dispatched to investigate. They determined the car was under pressure and was venting through the Vacuum relief valve. They were able to stop it by removing the valve and installing a plug. X-2025030993 During FRA Hazmat inspection the inspector heard possible hissing from the vacuum relief valve on tank car FURX130488. Inspector notified the RR and contractor determined car had pressure on it and it was coming out of the valve. Contractor replaced the VRV with a steel plug.

  • Description: Overfill company tank at terminal resulting in a spill contained by the dike with ULSD seeping into the gravel lot. Cleanup vendor assessed and confirmed that the containment unit for the UST had been overfilled, and had roughly 3-4 inches of standing diesel in the bottom of the containment unit. Estimated release of 200-300 gallons with the large majority of product confined to the containment unit. Approximately 23 gallons splashed out and reached the ground. CDG managed this spill cleanup and notified NCDEQ.

The release impacted the trailer floor. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 10-gallons of UN3264 Octave product released to a 15’x8’ area of the trailer floor due to load shifting during transit and puncturing drum. The contactors neutralized the material with sodium bicarbonate and solidifying the release with oil dri. The waste generated was containerized into (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.description:

  • City: EIGHTY FOUR

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 10000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted an area measuring approximately 15ft-by-20ft of the concrete terminal floor and estimated that thirty (30) gallons of material was released due to one (1) 275-gallon poly tote being crushed and punctured by a forklift. Clean Harbors personnel deployed granular absorbents and used absorbent pads to collect the spent material. The remaining product in the damaged tote was transferred to a new tote. The damaged tote was cut-up and along with the recovered spent absorbents were placed into four (4) 55-gallon poly drums. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

item.description:
Report E-2025030270

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-25T18:19:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-20
  • City: ELKHART
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SET Environmental personnel were dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, they observed an estimated two (2) ounces of material released from one (1) 330-gallon IBC plastic tote due to a loose cap on a faulty lid. SET Environmental personnel observed that the released material impacted the top of the IBC tote. SET Environmental personnel used absorbent pads to wipe down the container and containerized them into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum along with 2 drum liners. The incident generated a total of one (1) waste container. Contractor personnel replaced the lid of the IBC tote. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization. The waste generated will remain onsite for the Dayton Freight team to coordinate disposal.

  • Description: On March 20, 2025, three (3) 5-gallon jugs of UN3098 were punctured and released approximately four (4) gallons of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the site. The crew neutralized the materials and collected the spent product with hand tools. All impacted materials and the damaged jugs were containerized in five (5) 35-gallon drums.

The outer fiberboard box did not have any DG markings or paperwork required for transit. It was place into a steel salvage package and is being held for the FAA.

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-12
  • City: TAMPA
  • State: FL

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: ONE AIR PACKAGE WAS INSPECTED DUE DANGEROUS GOODS TRIGGERS VISIBLE ON THE OUTER BOX. THERE IS A SQUARE SHAPE CUT FROM THE BOX. THERE IS A WHITE LABEL AFFIXED INDICATING 25180WHT 5,000 MAH RPET POWER BANK WHITE. THERE IS ALSO A WHITE LABEL INDICATING REJECT REASON: ORDER CAN NOT BE SHIPPED WITH AN AIR SERVICE. UPON INSPECTION OF INNER CONTENTS THERE ARE FORTY-FIVE POWER BANKS, CAPACITY 5000MAH, 3.7V. THEY ARE IMPRINTED POWERFLEX EDF RENEWABLES. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX. THE PACKAGE WAS SCANNED INTO AN AIR CONTAINER BUT DID NOT MOVE IN THE AIR NETWORK.

item.title: Report E-2025030257
item.description:
Report E-2025030257

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-25T18:19:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-28
  • City: KNOXVILLE
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 10000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: First Call Environmental-LTL was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, they observed an estimated five to six (5-6) gallons of material released from one (1) 55-gallon plastic drum that was punctured by a forklift. First Call Environmental-LTL personnel observed that the released material impacted 15 ft-by-10 ft of trailer floor and asphalt. First Call Environmental-LTL personnel deployed a neutralizer and granular absorbents to the impacted area and containerized them into two (2) 55-gallon poly drums. The drums also contained PPE, debris, and boom. The punctured drum was placed into a metal drum by the terminal, but due to the corrosive nature First Call Environmental-LTL placed the damaged drum into one (1) 85-gallon plastic drum. Generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization. The waste generated will remain onsite for the ESTES team to coordinate disposal
